top_comment.text: why  not de-extinction be made for deceased relatives ?﻿
top_comment.author: Hloea Adleviade

comments.text:
+BathroomTile i think you misunderstood me. my point is reviving family 
bloodlines. for example, if the last bloodline (person) of a certain family 
died, then you can use his/her DNA to revive that family bloodline.
comments.author: Hloea Adleviade

comments.text:
+Cheff Illidan
Look, I guess in the end, your point is "why can't I bring back my deceased 
aunt through cloning so that i can talk to her about that vacation years 
ago over tea and biscuits?", right? Ok, let's say they clone your aunt 
using her DNA. A replica of your aunt at your desired age wouldn't plop out 
the end of a machine. A baby would have to be born. And that baby would be 
genetically identical to your aunt, back in the 1930's. And then someone 
would have to raise her in today's society. She'd have new memories, new 
relatives, most likely a new personality.
Basically, she'd be a totally different person from your aunt, you wouldn't 
be able to relate to her like you did
 and she wouldn't have any of her memories.
So I don't really see the use for it. You'd just be doing the same as 
making a new baby the normal way. The point of cloning a bison isn't to 
bring that very same bison to life, it's to bring the whole species to life.
comments.author: BathroomTile

comments.text:
Like someone said, it is not de-extinction because the human race is not 
exctinct.
If you're talking about "reviving" someone by cloning them, it is illegal 
in most countries for ethical reasons. I don't think it has ever been done 
on humans. There are theorical methods, and animals have been cloned, but 
not humans. If you tried to extract someone's genes from their (dead or 
not) body to create a perfect copy of them, the copy would still not be 
perfect as there are other mechanisms in the human body that affect 
diversity. (epigenetics for example)
comments.author: Hopper x

comments.text:
+Cheff Illidan
Maybe.
But we can get into details like the original having more antibodies or 
different antibodies compared to the clone. But hey, it's the best donor 
for blood transfusion and organs!
I don't have a scientific background yet so I'm just sharing what I know.

comments.author: Hloea Adleviade

comments.text:
+Cheff Illidan Imagine a factory that processes two identical hard drives. 
Then sends those off to two different computers in two different places 
owned by two different people. Near the beginning of their lives, they 
would be incredibly similar. But as new information is brought to the hard 
drives they quickly change into very different operating individuals. It 
would come to a point where their jobs would be very different, their 
memories or in this case files would be incredibly different, and finally 
they would also act very different due to their experiences. Perhaps one 
has broken down due to over use or over heating, perhaps the other is 
slower because it's been bogged down by too much information.

No one would think of these two identically made HD's as been the same HD. 
Just like no one would think of those humans the same just because they 
were made the same. It's what happens in your time here on earth that makes 
up who you are.
comments.author: losveratos

comments.text:
so ..... basically the same human (via DNA) but different? doesn't the DNA 
contains instructions that define a human ? so, shouldn't it be still the 
same human ?
comments.author: Hloea Adleviade

comments.text:
Human beings are not an extinct species.

De-extinction involves extracting DNA from the mummy and cloning it. Human 
cloning is illegal across most of the planet, and we don't quite have the 
technology to do it reliably,
Even if we did, it wouldn't bring back a deceased individual. It'd just 
create a new human being with the same genome. Environmental factors and 
human experience would be totally different for the clone, and result in 
them being a totally different person.
comments.author: Gringat Vaelestryne

comments.text:
First, you need a fully intact genome of the species you want to bring 
back. Second, you need a modern "cousin" of that species to be alive.

In ovoviviparous species, if you have the two above: it's "easy" and has 
already been done with some fish, toads and birds. But it's actually 
expensive and can take a long time, since needs 3 generations to have the 
exincted one hatching the egg.

For mammals, there's a bigger problem: the animals chosen to be the 
"mothers" of the species who you want to bring back would suffer a lot of 
stress and miscarriages until the expertiment finally succeed, this can be 
very traumatizing and even fatal to some individuals. They can also give 
birth to animals with malformations who would also suffer unnecessarily.

The benefits of bringing back extinct animals, are minimal for science, 
since the possible ones are most recent and  it's only minor things that we 
don't know about them. For enviromental reasons, you'll need a LOT of 
prolific individuals to really bring the species back from the status of 
"extict", and also in most cases the original habitat of the extinct 
species is already gone too. The only other reason would be for 
entertaining.
So, to the "science" point of view, none of these reasons are worth the 
pain, stress and suffering of the animals involved on the experience.

TL;DR: ethics.
comments.author: Renan Martins

No, it wouldn't, because the searches would not be geographically

higher-than-normal searches.

comments.text:
+MrDennis21jel You're making a very common mistake.  You're taking the 
actions of an individual and expecting it to influence statistical truths 
about a large group of people.  You can't do that.  Being a hypochondriac 
and searching a disease will have no effect on the statistics.  The only 
way it could have an effect is if a significant percentage of the overall 
population were hypochondriacs.  We know this is not the case because of 
studies like this video talked about.  They found that if they used search 
data to predict the spread of disease that it worked well.  If you hear 
that and conclude that individuals only search for diseases when sick, 
you're misinterpreting the data.  They are talking about the actions of 
large groups which is almost totally unrelated to individuals.
comments.author: Dustin Rodriguez

rocket being used in space, a rocket uses so much power, so much thrust, 
that even though the outcome changes between atmosphere and no atmosphere, 
the change is so little in respect to the energy being used to propel the 
rocket, that essentially nothing changes. And when it comes to the Voyager 
reaching Triton, and other such celestial bodies, we must remember that 
these celestial bodies are constantly moving at high speeds. So, maybe it 
reached Triton at the pace it did to ensure it passed by Triton at the most 
opportune time. I hope this answers your questions, and again, not a 
scientist in any respect. This is simply observation through knowledge I 
have gathered in my short life.

comments.text:
+The Real Flenuan I'll cite just one of my previous points . The velocity 
that all past spacecraft have achieved is about the same as the crafts 
escape velocity . If we could accelerate to any meaningful extent while in 
the vacuum of space would not this be to our advantage . The Voyager has 
just now reached Triton . Wouldn't it have been much better to have reached 
this point 15 years earlier and saved all the possible attrition to its 
components that the lapse of time might engender . All it would require is 
a secondary " thrust " rocket that the craft would carry into space to 
provide the additional speed but this was not done . Why ? Why haven't any 
space missions been provided with such ? Could it be that " thrust " 
requires something to push against ? See how logic works ? This is directly 
to the original question of Jacob Mcadams and my original response to that 
comment . So , any counter assertions or supporting arguments ?

top_comment.text:
You said it so well, but I thought it couldn't harm to add something to the 
conversation: Yeah, it's awesome with internet prediction, but I'm very 
sure that it wouldn't work in most of Scandinavia. English is becoming more 
and more of a 2nd mother tongue to us, with children starting to learn the 
language earlier and earlier on, and more multicultural influences in 
general. Plus, everybody knows that English Wikipedia is better than the 
Norwegian in pretty much every area, even stuff exclusively interesting to 
Norwegians. I think Sweden actually is further ahead in this progress, but 
don't quote me on that, as it is only an impression I've gotten. No, not 
only through Pewdiepie.﻿

comments.text:
I have a nephew and niece in sweden, age 10 and 15, both speak fluent 
english, dutch and swedish. They learned dutch because the family is dutch. 
English on school and at home, I think. Now that I think of it, my whole 
family is trilingual or multilingual so maybe it just runs in the family.

In Ontario, we learn French (mandatory) from Grade 1 to Grade 9, at which

comments.text:
+TeamFlamingStones
Yeah, the guy that founded American Sign language literally went on a trip 
around europe in search of signed language, after being inspired by his 
deaf neighbor learning a sign. He then shipped away this one deaf french 
dude to america, and the rest is history.

direct translation of the english version with gaps), most of us will use

comments.author: Christina Hunt

comments.text:
SciShow Space covered that (SciShow's space and astronomy based affiliated 
channel).  The sound is the hum being created by the electromagnetic field 
of the comet and was amplified many thousands of times to become audible 
for humans.

captions.text: [Intro]

It shouldn't surprise you to hear that I think
science and the internet go fantastic together.

I mean, most of the time. Yeah, once a year
or so, the internet tries to convince us that

the Yellowstone Supervolcano is going to explode
just because some bison are running down a

road or something, and it did convince some
people that the world was gonna end in 2012,

but the internet is also why you have me.
And it turns out that this thing that we are

using here together is surprisingly good at
monitoring the health of our species.

According to new research published this week,
public health officials have been able to

accurately track and even predict the spread
of diseases by studying how often those diseases

have been looked up on Wikipedia. Scientists
at Los Alamos National Laboratory were able

to successfully monitor influenza outbreaks
in the United States, Poland, Japan, and Thailand,

as well as Dengue Fever in Brazil by monitoring
the number of views received by pages related

to those diseases. The team was also able
to forecast half of the outbreaks they studied

at least 28 days in advance. The results suggest
that people start researching the diseases

online when they, or people they know, begin
to show symptoms, but before they get medical

attention. Scientists were able to track Wikipedia
searches, thanks to the site's open source

access logs. These logs show how many times
a page is view an hour and in what language.

So, for example, since the majority of people
who speak Thai live in Thailand, scientists

could monitor the access log for the Thai
page for influenza and get a sense of the

disease's prevalence there. They also monitored
pages having to do with specific symptoms,

like chills, fever, and headache. Then, they
aggregated all of this data into a computer

model and compared it with the actual weekly
reports of seven diseases in nine countries.

Their method worked particularly well in countries
that spoke a single language that wasn't spoken

in other countries, like Thailand or Poland,
but it also worked well in tracking influenza

in the US and Dengue Fever in Brazil, which
surprised the scientists, because those countries

use two of the most commonly spoken languages,
English and Portuguese. They think that their

predictions still worked because the US dominates
the English speaking internet landscape, while

Brazil is the only Portuguese speaking country
that has Dengue. As you can probably guess,

we are still a long way from the internet
being able to predict our next public health

crisis for us. Not only are there problems
with using language as a proxy for nationality,

but more importantly, the model can only track
people who have internet access, and by some

estimates, that's only about 35% of the world's
population. Plus, the monitoring only worked

for diseases that develop quickly and tend
to appear in seasonal cycles. So while it

was effective at tracking influenza and Dengue,
it was of no help in forecasting rates of

Tuberculosis or HIV infections. Still, the
study is yet another step toward harnessing

the power of the internet for the aims of
science, and it's always good to see those
two gettin' along.

Alright, now, if you're like us, few things
thrill you more than finding really old dead

things, especially if they're frozen. And
if that's the case, you were probably as excited

as we were when the news came about the Yukagir
Mummy, the most complete, naturally preserved

bison ever found. First discovered in 2011
in the permafrost of Eastern Siberia, the

mummy is a 9000 year old Steppe Bison, a species
that became extinct at the end of the last

Ice Age. Its organs are almost fully preserved
and include a heart and stomach, lungs, intestines,

and a brain. He still has fur and a tail and
even the tips of his little ears. An autopsy

performed by Russian researchers showed that
the bison died when he was about four years

old, and that he had very low body fat, suggesting
he may have starved to death. But Yukagir

is not the first bison mummy scientists have
discovered.

There are actually four of them, including
a 36,000 year old specimen unearthed by Alaskan

gold miners during the 1970s. But all of these
mummies were either scavenged by animals or

partly destroyed by the freezing and thawing.
But Yukagir wasn't, so the data that we'll

glean from him will help us better understand
all kinds of things about the long-gone Steppe

Bison, from what they ate, to what parasites
they carried, to where they roamed. And yes,

I know you're wondering, so I'll tell you
that researchers have gotten fragments of

DNA from the bison's hair, which will help
clarify how Steppe Bison are related to modern-day

bison and cattle. But in case you're having
dreams of riding a Steppe Bison in some futuristic

Pleistocene theme park, there are no plans
to use that DNA to bring the Steppe Bison

back through a process known as resurrection
biology, or de-extinction.

So I'm sorry to burst that particular bubble,
but thank you for joining me here on SciShow

News. If you want to help us share science
with the world, which we couldn't do without

support from people like you, you can become
a supporting subscriber at Subbable.com/SciShow,

and if you just want to keep getting smarter
with us, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow
and subscribe.
